name: Muslim Academy of Greater Orlando
mission: The mission of the Muslim Academy of Greater Orlando is to provide quality education of the highest standard in a safe, supportive, dynamic, and engaging Islamic environment so that students have the opportunity to excel to their fullest potential.
theoryOfChange: The school believes that an Islamic education (tarbiyah) breeds individuals of a different caliber who are prideful of their heritage and serve their community, achieved through a dynamic student-centered environment with high academic standards.
zakatClaimEvidence: No explicit mention of zakat on the Muslim Academy of Greater Orlando's donation pages or website. The donation platform states, "Muslim Academy of Greater Orlando hasn't set up any donation plans yet." (Source: https://magorlando.net/26-27-tuition-%26-fees)

ui_signals_v1.recommendation_rationale: Context dependent profile. Consider cause fit, risk profile, and evidence maturity before deciding.

components.improvement_suggestion: Add a dedicated zakat page or clearly state whether donations are zakat-eligible.

components.improvement_suggestion: Expand services to underserved populations or geographies with limited nonprofit coverage.

components.improvement_suggestion: If reserves are above policy target, document why and publish triggers for planned deployment.

score_details.score_summary: Muslim Academy of Greater Orlando Inc shows moderate impact and moderate alignment (significant risk deductions applied).

all_citations.claim: The organization reported total revenue of $3,572,587 and a program expense ratio of 67.8%.
Financial metadata indicates the organization holds 15.6 months of working capital and a fundraising efficiency of $0.00 per $1 raised.
The Muslim Academy of Greater Orlando provides quality education focused on virtue, wisdom, and strength.
The academy offers a structured educational program for students in Kindergarten through Grade 8.
The organization provides a dedicated Pre-K education program.
The academy, also known as MAGO, continues its mission to provide quality education into the 2026-27 academic year.
The organization maintains specific admission requirements for its early childhood programs.
The organization accepts charitable donations and provides information on tuition and fees.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization earns a moderate score of 45/100, reflecting a stable financial position and clear educational mission balanced by a need for improved program spending ratios and more robust impact data.
areas_for_improvement: Increase the program expense ratio to ensure a higher percentage of revenue is directed toward direct educational services.
Enhance transparency and data reporting to improve third-party impact assessments.

dimension_explanations.alignment: As a Sadaqah-eligible institution, the academy serves the urgent global cause of education within an Islamic framework [3][8]. However, the alignment score of 24/50 reflects a relatively low donor fit for those seeking high-directness interventions, as the academy operates as a tuition-based private school with specific admission requirements [4][7].
dimension_explanations.impact: The academy focuses on capacity building through long-term educational enrollment, reporting total revenue of $3,572,587 to support its facilities and staff [1][2]. While the organization maintains a healthy 15.6 months of working capital, its program expense ratio of 67.8% suggests that a significant portion of funds is allocated to administrative or secondary costs rather than direct student services [1].

baseline_narrative.headline: The Muslim Academy of Greater Orlando provides a comprehensive educational foundation rooted in virtue, wisdom, and strength for students from Pre-K through eighth grade.
strengths: Maintains a robust liquidity position with 15.6 months of working capital available for operations.
Demonstrates high fundraising efficiency with a cost of $0.00 per $1 raised.
Offers a continuous educational pathway from early childhood through middle school.
baseline_narrative.summary: The Muslim Academy of Greater Orlando (MAGO) is a non-profit educational institution dedicated to providing quality education to children in the Greater Orlando area [3][6]. The academy operates structured academic programs including Pre-K education and a comprehensive curriculum for Kindergarten through Grade 8 [4][5].

areas_for_improvement.context: The organization currently reports a <cite id="14">board size of only 1 member</cite>, which limits independent oversight and institutional checks and balances.
There is currently <cite id="15">no publicly available beneficiary data</cite> to assess the cost-effectiveness of educational delivery per student.

bbb_assessment.summary: The organization does not currently meet BBB standards due to its <cite id="14">single-member board</cite>.

case_against.mitigation_notes: The organization's long history and significant asset base provide some mitigation against immediate financial risk.
risk_factors: <cite id="14">Single-member board governance</cite> creates significant operational risk
case_against.summary: The primary concerns involve <cite id="14">insufficient board oversight</cite> and a lack of <cite id="15">standardized impact reporting</cite>.

confidence.data_freshness: Financial data current through 2024 tax year
confidence.notes: Strong financial growth data but significant transparency gaps regarding governance and outcomes.

credibility.explanation: The academy is a verified entity with <cite id="1">nearly 20 years of operating history</cite>, but credibility is hampered by <cite id="14">limited board independence</cite> and a lack of external transparency seals.
credibility.improvement: To strengthen credibility, the academy should expand its board to include more independent members and <cite id="15">publish annual impact reports</cite>.

impact.explanation: The school shows high directness in its <cite id="6">67.8% program expense ratio</cite>, but the <cite id="15">absence of cost-per-beneficiary data</cite> prevents a full efficiency rating.
impact.improvement: The academy should <cite id="15">publish student enrollment counts</cite> consistently so that cost-effectiveness can be accurately assessed.

rich_narrative.headline: The Muslim Academy of Greater Orlando provides a comprehensive educational foundation rooted in virtue, wisdom, and strength for students from Pre-K through eighth grade.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for local donors in Florida who wish to support the long-term infrastructure and growth of an established Islamic K-8 educational institution through sadaqah.
donor_motivations: Want to support local Islamic education in the Greater Orlando area
Value organizations with strong financial liquidity and no debt
Prefer supporting established institutions with a 20-year track record
Interested in funding school expansion and professional development
giving_considerations: The organization has a very small board which may impact long-term governance
Detailed student outcome data is not publicly shared

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade C reflects that while the school is operational and verified, it lacks <cite id="15">publicly available outcome data</cite> or independent evaluations.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: The academy creates impact by providing a structured Islamic environment and academic curriculum to students, preparing them for higher education.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence ensures that educational programs are effectively meeting student learning objectives and community needs.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: The academy's rapid revenue growth and <cite id="19">$3.6M funding gap</cite> suggest it can absorb significant capital for facility or program expansion.

peer_comparison.differentiator: Distinguished by an exceptionally high <cite id="9">working capital ratio</cite> compared to the <cite id="18">89.6% peer median program ratio</cite>.

strengths.detail: The academy maintains a robust financial cushion with <cite id="9">15.6 months of working capital</cite> available for operations, ensuring long-term sustainability.
The organization operates with a fundraising efficiency of <cite id="10">$0.00 per $1 raised</cite>, meaning nearly all donor contributions are available for institutional use.
The academy has achieved a <cite id="5">25.5% revenue CAGR</cite> over the last three years, indicating strong community support and expansion.

strengths_deep_dive: The Muslim Academy of Greater Orlando's financial health is anchored by its significant asset base and efficient capital management. With <cite id="11">total assets of $3,270,864</cite>, the school has built a solid foundation for its <cite id="12">professional development programs</cite> and <cite id="13">service learning projects</cite>. This stability is further evidenced by a <cite id="9">working capital ratio of 17.6 months</cite> as reported by third-party analysts, providing a substantial buffer against economic volatility or enrollment fluctuations.
rich_narrative.summary: The Muslim Academy of Greater Orlando (MAGO) is an established educational institution that has served the Florida community since <cite id="1">its founding in 2006</cite>. The academy provides a comprehensive academic pathway, offering <cite id="2">Pre-K education</cite> alongside a <cite id="3">Kindergarten through Grade 8 curriculum</cite> designed to foster virtue and wisdom. Financially, the organization has demonstrated significant growth, reporting <cite id="4">total revenue of $3,572,587</cite> in the 2024 tax year, which represents a <cite id="5">three-year revenue CAGR of 25.5%</cite>. While the organization maintains a <cite id="6">67.8% program expense ratio</cite> according to its most recent filings, it operates with a lean administrative structure. The academy's operations are supported by a mix of <cite id="7">$3,093,110 in contributions</cite> and <cite id="8">$479,477 in program service revenue</cite>, primarily from tuition and fees. Despite its growth, the organization faces challenges regarding governance transparency and formal impact reporting, which are reflected in its current evaluation scores.
